Sylvain Gaillard, Paris, France (sylvaing.gaillard@polytechnique.edu)
Stéphane Gaiffas, LPSM, Université de Paris, Ecole normale supérieure, Paris, France (stephane.gaiffas@polytechnique.edu)
Emmanuel Bacry, CEREMADE, Université Paris Dauphine, Paris, France (emmanuel.bacry@polytechnique.edu)

Abstract:
Estimating the amount of electricity that can be produced by rooftop photovoltaic systems is a time-consuming process that requires on-site measurements, a difficult task to achieve on a large scale. This paper presents an approach to estimate the solar potential of rooftops based on their location and architectural characteristics, as well as the amount of solar radiation they receive annually. Our technique uses computer vision to achieve semantic segmentation of roof sections and roof objects, and a machine learning model based on structured building features to predict roof pitch. We then compute the azimuth and maximum number of solar panels that can be installed on a rooftop using geometric approaches. Finally, we compute precise shading masks and combine them with solar irradiation data to estimate the yearly solar potential of a rooftop.

1. Introduction
The 21st century is characterized by an ever-increasing energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions that are contributing to climate change in an unprecedented way. Fossil fuels are still the main source of electricity and heat generation, accounting for 42% of greenhouse gas emissions in 2016. Energy efficiency and the development of renewable energies are presented as the two main approaches to lower these emissions, and photovoltaic solar energy is one of the fastest-growing renewable energy sources due to low maintenance and operation costs. Solar panels can produce energy anywhere there is enough sunlight without direct impact on the environment, making it possible to produce energy in dense environments such as cities or industrial zones.

To compute the solar potential of a building rooftop, we need two types of information: how many solar modules can be fitted on a roof section and how much energy each module could produce within a year, accounting for local irradiation and shading. This work proposes a methodology to answer these questions, as illustrated in Figure 1.

Figure 1: Workflow for a given building from the initial aerial image to its rooftop solar potential.

First, an image segmentation algorithm applied to aerial imagery is used to obtain each roof section 2D geometry and any obstructing objects it may contain (Section 2.1). The roof 3D geometry (pitch/azimuth) is obtained through a combination of geometric methods and a Random Forest algorithm (Section 2.2). Then, the maximum number of modules fitting on a section is computed using a geometric packing algorithm (Appendix). A shading mask is computed from the shadows cast by surrounding buildings and relief, and the specific photovoltaic power is computed from meteorological data, module orientation, and shading effects (Section 2.3). Finally, the total amount of energy produced by a given roof section in a year can be computed by multiplying the number of modules, the module's nominal power, and its specific photovoltaic power.

2. Methodology
2.1 Roof and object segmentation
The first step in our pipeline is to subdivide roof sections as well as the equipment present on them. This will help us understand how much space is available on a roof for it to be equipped with solar panels. We split this task into two semantic segmentation tasks, consisting in classifying each pixel of an image into one of multiple classes. We developed one model that segments the images into background, roof sections, and roof ridges, and one that subdivides the images into background and a set of chosen roof objects. Roof sections are eventually enhanced by geometrical regularization (see Appendix).

Figure 2: Two examples of aerial image and roof sections semantic segmentation pairs. Sections are depicted in blue, ridges in yellow.

Both segmentation models consist of a U-Net architecture using a ResNet-34 feature extractor as backbone. The main dataset used in this work is the set of aerial images obtained from the IGN (French National Institute of Geographic and Forest Information) dataset. Building footprints were also obtained from the same source. Roof geometries labels are obtained from the 3D city representations of five different French cities. No roof object dataset was found, and we relied instead on a set of 423 manually tagged images including object type (smoke vent, roof window, etc.) and geometry.
